verses.text: Clap your hands, all you peoples! Shout to God with a voice of triumph!
verses.comment: This call to worship is given to all the nations, pointing forward to a time when God’s kingdom will include every people. There is a foreshadowing here of the universality of God’s plan, which finds fulfillment in the New Testament with the inclusion of the Gentiles (see Acts 15:16-17).

verses.text: For the LORD Most High is awe-inspiring; he is the great King over all the earth.
verses.comment: The title 'Most High' underscores God's supreme authority, not only over Israel but over all nations. This looks ahead to the universal reign of the Messiah (Ps. 2:6-8).

verses.text: He subdues peoples under us, and nations under our feet.
verses.comment: This verse points to the ultimate victory and inheritance of God’s chosen people, which later comes to include all who are united to Christ, echoing Romans 16:20.

verses.text: He chooses our inheritance for us, the pride of Jacob whom he loves. Selah.
verses.comment: God’s choice of inheritance points to God’s sovereign grace in the history of redemption. In Christian understanding, this finds its fulfillment in our inheritance in Christ (Eph. 1:11). The language of ‘choosing’ also foreshadows the necessity of a divinely appointed ministry and sacraments.

verses.text: God has gone up with a shout, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet.
verses.comment: This alludes to God's exaltation, and for Christians, prefigures Christ’s Ascension. The mention of trumpets evokes liturgical worship, central to biblical faith, and establishes a model of worship with ceremony and music.

verses.text: Sing praises to God, sing praises! Sing praises to our King, sing praises!
verses.comment: The repetition emphasizes the joy and importance of praise. The tradition of sacred music continues in Christian worship, reflecting the heavenly liturgy (Rev. 5:8-14).

verses.text: For God is the King of all the earth; sing praises with understanding.
verses.comment: Worship should be done with both heart and mind. The call to 'sing with understanding' stresses the necessity of teaching and instruction in the faith, which the early Church fulfilled through catechesis and tradition.

verses.text: God reigns over the nations; God sits on his holy throne.
verses.comment: God’s throne symbolizes his unending rule and his holiness. The spiritual sense points to Christ’s eternal reign, now made present especially in the assembly of believers who worship in unity.

verses.text: The princes of the peoples gather as the people of the God of Abraham. For the shields of the earth belong to God; he is greatly exalted.
verses.comment: The gathering of the nations around the God of Abraham points toward the unity of all peoples in one faith, fulfilling the promises to Abraham. The 'shields' symbolize rulers; all earthly authority is ultimately subject to God. This prefigures the unity of all believers under one divine shepherd as seen in John 10:16.
